question: Which activity conserves water: planting crops that survive in droughts or planting crops that require lots of water?

content.source_1: In many crop plants, drought conditions trigger reduced stomatal opening or temporary stomatal closure during the hottest, driest parts of the day.
content.source_2: Lower stomatal opening reduces transpiration, the primary pathway for water loss from leaves.
content.source_3: Several drought-tolerant crops (e.g., sorghum and some grapevine cultivars) maintain relatively open stomata under moderate drought to sustain photosynthesis and evaporative cooling, relying instead on deep rooting and osmotic adjustment.
content.source_4: Submerged aquatic plants have few or nonfunctional stomata on underwater leaves and do not use stomatal closure as a water-conservation mechanism.
content.source_5: Prolonged stomatal closure severely limits CO2 uptake and can depress growth and yield during drought in many crops.
content.source_6: In breeding programs for drought tolerance, genotypes that maintain stomatal conductance under water stress often yield better than those that close stomata strongly.

answer: planting crops that survive in droughts
